First, some background:

I'm fairly new to unit testing, but I'm very much interested in it. 
I've begun to understand the basics of it, but I'm about to start
implementing for a class that is far and above more complex than the
simple tutorial classes that I've used for training purposes.

Now, my issues:

Assume I have a  Servlet has a service() method being called. Assume
also that I can't replicate the servlet environment  so I'm using Mock
Objects ( http://mockobjects.sourceforge.net ) to keep the testing
light. 

If my service() method looks like this:

service() {

  doSomething()
  doAnotherThing()
  doSomethingElse() 
}

each of which require the setting of a significantly different state (
or MockObjects inside MockObjects, which I've read breaks the
fundamental philosophy of unit testing and mock objects )

would it suffice to test doSomething(), doAnotherThing(),
doSomethingElse() or would good practice dictate that I test service()
since that's the method that will be involved in the integration of my
code with the rest of the system?

I guess my underlying questions are:

What are some guidelines for a "unit" ?
Is the assumption of tested units enough to warrant passing on the
composite methods that call those units?

Thanks for any help,

Aadi
